docs.lead_paragraph: It looks as if Congress may be ready to require that insurance coverage for mental illness and substance abuse be provided on the same terms as coverage for physical ailments.

headline.main: Facing Terrible News, and Going On (2 Letters)
headline.print_headline: Facing Terrible News, And Going On

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors say the soaring cost of new vaccines makes it difficult for them to buy the shots they give their patients.

headline.main: Pediatricians Voice Anger Over Costs of Vaccines
headline.print_headline: In Need of a Booster Shot

docs.snippet: Doctors say the soaring cost of new vaccines makes it difficult for them to buy the shots they give their patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's pediatricians, the foot soldiers in the campaign to vaccinate America's children, are starting to revolt. The soaring cost and rising number of new vaccines, doctors say, make it increasingly difficult for them to buy the shots they give their patients. They also complain that insurers often do not reimburse them enough, so they can lose money on every dose they deliver.

headline.main: In Need of a Booster Shot; Rising Costs Make Doctors Balk at Giving Vaccines

docs.abstract: American pediatricians say soaring costs and rising number of new vaccines make it increasignly difficult for them to buy shots they give their patients; complain that insurers often do not reimburse them enough, so that they lose money on vaccinations; some pediatricians are not offering newest and most expensive vaccines; some public health experts say US immunization program could break down and preventable diseases could increase; photos; chart (M)
docs.snippet: The nation's pediatricians, the foot soldiers in the campaign to vaccinate America's children, are starting to revolt.      The soaring cost and rising number of new vaccines, doctors say, make it increasingly difficult for them to buy the shots they...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Deeply Split House Votes To End War by Late '08 A deeply divided House of Representatives voted to bring most American combat troops home from Iraq next year, with Democrats employing their new Congressional majority to create the most forceful challenge yet to President Bush's war policy. A1 Inquest on London Bombing The British police began interrogating three men apprehended under counterterrorism laws for alleged offenses related to the July 7, 2005, suicide bombings on the London transit system. In a separate case, evidence emerged of a possible link between the bombings and a failed attack two weeks later. A7 Sunni Deputy Premier Wounded Iraq's deputy Sunni prime minister, Salam al-Zubaie, suffered chest wounds from shrapnel when one of his guards blew himself up as Mr. Zubaie led mid-day prayers. The explosion left nine people dead and appeared to be another in the mounting number of cases of Sunni-on-Sunni violence. A7 Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations said that a mortar shell that landed near him in Baghdad had surprised and scared him but would not deter him from expanding his organization's presence in Iraq. A3 Plane Shot Down Over Somalia A cargo plane was shot down over Mogadishu's livestock market, a known hide-out for insurgents, witnesses and Somali officials said. According to government officials, the plane was ferrying technicians working for the African Union peacekeeping force in Somalia. A4 Iran Seizes 15 on British Ship Fifteen British sailors and marines carrying out an inspection in the Persian Gulf were seized and taken into custody by Iranian naval forces, the British government said. A7 NATIONAL A8-11 Gonzales and Advisers Met 10 Days Before Firings Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales and senior advisers discussed the plan to remove seven United States Attorneys at a meeting on Nov. 27, 2006, 10 days before the dismissals were carried out, according to a Justice Department calendar entry. A1 Ex-Official Pleads Guilty J. Steven Griles, the second-highest official at the Interior Department during President Bush's first term, pleaded guilty to lying before a Senate committee about his ties to Jack Abramoff, the disgraced lobbyist who is now in prison. A9 Rat Poison Found in Pet Food Rat poison has been found in pet food blamed for the deaths of 14 animals, federal and New York State officials said, but they said they were unsure how it got there. A8 Texas May Release Youths Battered by a sexual abuse scandal in the juvenile justice system, Texas may free most of the 4,000 jailed youths who have served their minimum sentences but are still being held for often indeterminate reasons. A8 Senate Passes Budget The Senate passed a Democratic spending outline that proponents said would balance the federal budget by 2012, provide more money for programs like children's health care and extend some of President Bush's tax cuts beyond 2010. A11 No Degree for Jeb Bush The Faculty Senate at the University of Florida, the largest university in the state, rejected a proposal to award former Gov. Jeb Bush an honorary degree. Some members openly criticized his policies. A9 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Play on War in Iraq Divides a High School A play written by the advanced theater class at Wilton High School in Wilton, Conn., about the war in Iraq, compiled from reflections of soldiers and others involved, was canceled by the school's principal, causing the latest in a series of free-speech squabbles at the school. B1 Dancer's Killer Sentenced Paul Cortez, an actor and yoga teacher convicted of killing Catherine Woods, a young dancer in Manhattan, was sentenced to 25 years to life in prison. B1 Gifts to Labor Chief Questioned Carla Katz, the former companion of Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey and the president of a state union, has long contended that she has no obligation to disclose large sums of money Mr. Corzine gave her when he was in the Senate. But in 2005, the United States Department of Labor formally requested that she disclose anything of value he gave her. B1 Religion Journal B5 BUSINESS DAY C1-9 Tax-Refund Loans Decline Refund anticipation loans from tax preparers like H&R Block and Jackson-Hewitt declined 22.5 percent last year as consumers used alternatives that are fast and less expensive. C1 Tax Cut Favors Foreigners President Bush's 2003 tax cuts include a provision that gives some foreign companies a financial advantage over competitors in the United States. C1 The Cost of Vaccines Pediatricians say soaring costs and low insurance reimbursements keep them from offering the newest and most costly vaccines. C1 Business Digest C2 OBITUARIES C10 Milton Wexler A psychoanalyst who applied his talent for conducting group therapy to brainstorming sessions for scientists working on the hereditary disease that ravaged his wife's family, he was 98. C10 EDITORIAL A12-13 Editorials: Mr. Spitzer's budget deals; fairness for mental health; unwary investors; legal convolutions for gay couples. Columns: Stanley Fish, Rory Stewart. Crossword B15 Bridge B15 TV Listings B17 Weather B18

docs.lead_paragraph: Democratic presidential contender John Edwards and his wife Elizabeth announced today that Mrs. Edwards's cancer had returned, this time in a rib on her right side.

headline.main: Edwards: 'The Campaign Goes On' Despite Wife's Cancer Recurrence

docs.abstract: The North Carolina senator says he'll tend to his wife while she battles another bout with cancer.
docs.snippet: The North Carolina senator says he'll tend to his wife while she battles another bout with cancer.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate has a chance to restore discipline to the federal budget, a first step in remedying years of damage from profligate tax cuts in the face of immense spending.
